storyInfo: Frost accompanies an old Sarkaz Hunter looking for a way back home in the endless icefields of Sami.

attributes.content: 'Elias, hope you're doing well.'
'I hear you went south. Right now, we might just be on opposite ends of this continent.'
'Sami is a tranquil and peaceful place. I like the environment and atmosphere here a lot. It reminds me of my home, at times.'
'I'm looking forward to Ash's reaction after she finds out we treated her map listing dangerous regions as a tourism guide.'
'Our goal is unanimous. There has to be a reason behind the crossing we made, and I'll find the answer.'
'The answers to strange questions are always hiding in strange places. Maybe one of us will be able to locate it.'
'Good luck.'
The hunter holds her breath and waits, finger on her trigger.
In her sight is a fowlbeast, wandering back and forth in the forest, leaving one footprint after another in the snow.
It too is a scavenger, seeking other life to allow its own to persist in this harsh environment.
It seems to have seen something, standing its slender neck straight, sharp beak aimed towards its prey.
In one and the same instant, it spreads its wings, and the hunter pulls the trigger.
So close!
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Very close.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: This is some rotten luck.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Some fowl are good at catching onto how the air moves. Some have especially sensitive claws, so they can sense the slightest tremor in the ground.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: For every different kind of prey, there's a different trick to concealing yourself.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Alright, that's a lesson learned. Luck's not so bad looking at it that way—what kind of fowl did I lose just now?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: You didn't. Its time just isn't up yet.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Is that written in the prophecy too?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: You still don't believe it.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I'm just... unable to comprehend it.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: You've always seemed like a smart hunter, since we first got to know each other. Ample experience, and keen too.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Let alone how healthy you still are. I honestly can't believe it when you say it...
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Experience isn't the end-all, nor is judgment critical. Your being on this journey at this very moment is already enough.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: 'On this earth, there are special rules to survival?'
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Exactly.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Right now, we should continue setting out north.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: If what we already know is accurate, it's just deserted tundra north of the forest. The further north we go, the less prey we can catch.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Chances are we probably just missed our last meal.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Don't be so uneasy. The prophecy only mentioned my death, but you—you'll find what you've been searching for all this time.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Several days before
A journey to where your life ends?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: I've seen it. I've seen my death in the prophecy already. But before it happens, I have a request.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Please, take me north. We'll start from here, and bear north straight, until we emerge from the woods. If I still haven't breathed my last by then, then let us keep on northward.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I've spent enough long, untroubled years in this little wood cabin. Before I die, I want to see some sights I've never seen before.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I'm old and frail now. This is a journey I can't complete alone. So, I must ask for your help.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Sir, if this is truly your last wish, then of course. I'll help you any way I can.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: But what I can't understand is, how are you certain your life's almost over? I'm not even sure how much 'head straight north' can count as a dream...
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: How funny. Even in Sami, nobody would call a Sarkaz 'Sir.'
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I respect you a lot.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: The prophecy remains clear. In the end, I will surely reach the place.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: This is my final request. Take me with you, just as the prophecy showed.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I won't have you help for nothing. At this journey's conclusion, I will provide a reward. And you will find what you've been searching for all this time.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: The place where only one moon shines.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: We're definitely advancing north, according to the compass. But the plant distribution and atmosphere in our surroundings show no stronger characteristics of a polar climate.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Whether it's the compass or common sense, something's gotta be wrong.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Sami allowed a Sarkaz to retire here—because many a thing here poses more trouble than an old devil man.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Let us go on. We haven't strayed from the course.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Why are you so sure? According to you, you'd never been here before, nor were you at all familiar.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: True, I have never set foot beyond the forest.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: But it's not experience we depend on to recognize reality. When you realize experience cannot allow you to see reality clearly, you will be one step closer to touching upon it.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Alright. Those sound like the words of someone with experience.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Regardless, I have to admit too much of this world is beyond my common sense... So, are we still heading onward?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Yes—*cough*, *cough* *cough*... We head onward.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Maybe... we could take a break for a moment.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: A fine suggestion. We still have time, and so do I.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Frost sweeps away a patch of snow by a tree, lays a layer of fallen leaves on top of it, and invites the old hunter to sit.
Thank you.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: This is day nine.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Prey is dwindling for sure. Supplies are scarce too—and we still need to figure out how to get back.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Don't mind me. After we reach the end of our journey, you will return alone.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I'm sorry, I still have some doubts.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Does the prophecy have some kind of concrete information, if you believe so firmly in it?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Like this journey's destination, or what kind of preparations we should make?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Or even more fundamentally, did this prophecy tell you should go someplace, or was this journey just a wish of yours...? I'm not quite sure.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Your confusion is understandable. When most have a problem, they can only act once they receive a definite answer.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: But prophecies never give answers. Prophecies do not work that way.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: But it did state clearly you would die?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Death is hardly an answer either.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I heard the people here mention 'prophecy' before I met you, too. Is it a common skill around these parts?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Truthfully, each and every one of us is capable of prophecy. We see the dark clouds gathering, and so know rain is about to fall. It's simple as that.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I'm still finding this hard to comprehend.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Then we can stop talking about prophecy, and turn simply to our travels.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Of course. You told me before how you'd been to a lot of places, too. If you still remember, that is.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Spires that bring down the rain, lakes under the sea, trenches buried beneath the ground, cities on the backs of behemoths. And as well as that, 'a nonexistent home.'
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: The stories all start intriguing, but you never finish telling them.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Of course I remember them, whether they were travels or stories.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: A journey should conclude when it's still worth reflecting on, and a story should end when its audience is still interested.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Ooh, that's definitely not an excuse to dismiss your audience.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Then let us pass the time. Allow me to finish telling my last story.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Remind me, where did I get to? No, no need. I remember now.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: In the end, I accompanied that cursed, vile beast as it found that caster. Indignantly, it asked: 'Where, after all, is my home?'
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: 'All beings have an origin. Since they have an origin, there must be a place they are born. Yet why do I not? Could it be my existence was never meant?'
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: The Caster answered: 'This is the rule of the curse. You exchanged your home for wisdom, and the power to make all people fear. But now you forever lost your home; true, you should not exist!'
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: The beast was full of anger, and desired to savage the Caster to death. But still it calmed down.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Revenge was of no avail. It would not solve the contradiction its own existence posed. And an irrational existence is preordained to disappear.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Finally, the cursed beast chose to run, incessantly. So long as it never stopped in any one place, no part of this land would come to mean 'home,' nor 'away' to it, anymore.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: How wise of the beast, to solve the crisis of its own existence so. However, I had no energy to continue to run with it. I could only choose to stay in my little wood hut, and while away the rest of my days.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: A very metaphorical story.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Through metaphor, one is acquainted with reality.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Not through experience, but through metaphor.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: You come to understand.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: So, the end of your prophesied journey is also something to do with 'home?'
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: That is exactly what I expect.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I'm still very curious. Before you settled down in Sami, just how many places did you go?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: More than enough. To the point my life could have ended at any point, and it would be no regretful thing.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: At times I was a mercenary, at times a hunter, and times more still a simple traveler.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Both you and I share that passion for adventure, it seems.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: 'A scene never before seen is a priceless treasure.'
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: We had to go far no matter what, to appreciate something worth the view.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Just as that vile beast that could never stop.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Another layer of metaphor.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Well, then. It's your turn.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Fellow traveler, surely you have plenty of stories worth sharing yourself.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: I've definitely got plenty of stories about my travels I could tell, but I'm worried they might be just as hard to understand for you.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: You come from a very distant place.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Distant for sure. Farther away than we can even perceive.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Then perhaps, you could say, it is far enough to be ancient?
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Now there's a tricky question to answer.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Never mind. I won't seek an answer. To appreciate a story hardly requires making every detail clear.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Please, continue telling.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Alright, if you're okay with listening.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: I've told this story to practically no one, but if you're going to understand where I come from, then it'll serve as a fine case.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: It's not some adventure to be proud of. It starts with an emergency landing.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: 'A journey into the unknown always makes me happy, despite the risks that often come with it. You understand, I could never refuse the call.'
'People always find gain in their travels. At times, it's scenes that bring happiness. At times, it's other ways of looking at the world.'
'Like that wise old hunter said, we're unable to tolerate the existence of questions with no answers. Just as if every lock has some key made to match.'
'But that's only wishful thinking. It's not the logic of what nature makes. It's kind of like a Zen thing, isn't it?'
'I'm trying to figure it out now. It might help us answer our question.'
We're here.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: So this is what's north of the forest?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: This is 'home.'
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: You mean these ruins?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Stumbling, the old hunter sits down, the long and arduous journey having taken the last of his energy.
He gazes at the ruined, broken walls before him, his expression like a man admiring the most beautiful scenery.
Atop these ruins, there once was a grand city.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: More than once it was destroyed, and more than once it was rebuilt.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Would a city really go in a place as desolate as this?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: And below the barrage of fire was once a sea of flowers, and above the scorched earth were once skyscrapers.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: 'Kazdel.'
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: As the prophecy told, it will in the end become the home of all Sarkaz.
attributes.name: Old Sarkaz Hunter

attributes.content: Hold on, something's wrong—
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: In an instant, the boundless scenery surrounding her collapses.
What's going on...
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Frost looks all around. Before her, and behind her, all that remains is endless tundra.
The path they came by is gone without a trace, like the morning dew, and the magnet of the compass in her hands is deathly still, pointed straight ahead.
The good news is we probably didn't lose our way.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: If this is also part of the metaphors you talked about... Sir?
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Frost only now realizes that the old man beside her is no longer breathing.
The old hunter looks towards the cold empty expanse, his face full of serenity.
A journey to where your life ends.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: This is your last wish granted, then.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Frost sits down to the side of the old hunter, and the two hunters together admire the landscape at the end of their journey.
There's—only one moon in the sky.
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Opposite where the sun sets, a single moon appears faint on the horizon. A pale silver silhouette, in the same shade as the boundless tundra.
Frost only learns later that upon this great land, this is a sight so very rarely seen.
'A scene never before seen is a priceless treasure.'
attributes.name: Frost

attributes.content: Alright. This is a reward I'm willing to take.
attributes.name: Frost
